name: Tales Of The Old West - System Assets
description:
Initialize Tales of the Old West RPG Core Rules
This will import key Tables into your world and organise them into folders.
These tables are included with the express permission of Effekt Publishing Ltd and remains their IP.

Tales of the Old West Core rules published by: Effekt Publishing Ltd. Effekt Publishing
Foundry Visualisation by Paul Watson
Thanks for their help, support to:
Frank Graeff, Peter Coutts, Douglas Painter, Jed McClure, Bruce Laing.

text.content:
Tales of The Old West

Tales of the Old West is a game about making your way in the West in the 1870s

Official system for playing Tales of the Old West on Foundry VTT.

The RollTables in the system have been included with the express permission of Effekt Publishing Ltd and remains their IP.

Developed for Foundry FTT by Paul Watson

If you like my system please consider buying me a coffee: https://ko-fi.com/paulwatson

Should you wish to populate the system with game content for your own use please purchase the rule book from Effekt Publishing or the Foundry Core Rules module.

Top Tips

Right Click is used quite a bit in the system. If in doubt, try it out.
Examples are:

  • Right click an edit button to choose delete / edit
  • Right click to clear radio buttons
  • Right click a “roll” to enter modifiers before a roll

Actors

There are four main types of Actors available in the system:

  • PC
  • NPC
  • Animal
  • Town Charter

In this section I will go over the common areas of the these sheets.

Items/Item Types

There are a number of Item types that can be created for use within the system:

  • Item - General equipment
  • Weapon - Personal and Vehicle weapons
  • Critical Injury - Create Critical injuries with modifiers
  • Animal Temperament - Animal Qualities & Flaws
  • Talent - Talents for use within the system
  • Amenities - Details town projects
  • Weapon Quality - Weapon Qualities & Conditions (Special Items)



Item

The item sheet is for generic items for use within the game.
The modifiers tab allows you to add any +/- effects using the item may have on the PCs attributes or skills.
   
Modifiers have an in-system effect once the item is "Active" (Not in your horses saddlebag).

Weapon

Select the type on the sheet (Ranged or Melee) and the sheet will dynamically change to the relevant stats for that weapon type. The Class field is a text field which allow you to classify the weapon. This is not a required field and can be left blank.
   
   
For a Melee weapon the range will be set to Engaged, for Ranged weapons select the appropriate range from the dropdown list. The Cost field will convert the input to a currency so all you need to enter is the number e.g., 15000 and it will reformat as US$15,000.00.

The stats on the sheet will be used in rolls when the weapon is "Active".

Talent

This item type enables you to create talents for your game either homebrew or from the rulebook by adding descriptions to the rich test field. When dragged on to a PCs sheet, these will appear on the Skills tab and can be viewed by the player by clicking on the name.

NOTE:
With the exception of the "Nerves of Steel" talent, which will automatically add -2 to Stress rolls and the "Pack Mule" talent which increases total Encumbrance, Talents do not currently have an effect in the system so any impact deriving from a Talent needs to be applied manually during the game.

For instance, the Compassion (Medic Talent) allows the PC to push their roll multiple times but the system will by default only allow a roll to be pushed once. In this situation the player should use the check box in the chat window "Allow multi-push".
When the situation complies with the Talent criteria the player checks the box, before pushing the roll, they then PUSH as normal and a Stress point is added to their sheet.

Critical Injury

Critical Injury items can be dragged on to PC sheets to record permanent injuries as well as apply the appropriate roll modifiers as defined on the Modifiers tab.

Recommended Add-on Modules

While not necessary to use the Tales of the old West system, I would recommend installing the following Add-on modules as they make the GM's job a lot easier:

  • Dice So Nice:
    Alien RPG supports 2 dice face types. The new version also allows the GM to add animated effects to dice rolls.
  • Quick Insert - Search Widget:
    Allows you to quickly search for assets and drag them directly on to the scene, sheets or rich text fields.

Location: Lower Leg

Injury: Twisted Ankle

Fatal: No

Healing Time: [[1d6]] Days

Immediate Effect: -1 to MOVE & FIGHTIN'

Long-Term Effect: None

Location: Lower Leg

Injury: Broken Foot

Fatal: No

Healing Time: [[3d6]] Days

Immediate Effect: -1 to MOVE, cannot Run

Long-Term Effect: None

Location: Lower Leg

Injury: Broken Knee

Fatal: No

Healing Time: [[1d6]] Weeks

Immediate Effect: Cannot Run or MOVE. Walks at half pace

Long-Term Effect: 33% chance of walking with a limp.

Location: Head

Injury: Terrible Hit to the Head

Fatal: Yes / Instant

Healing Time: -

Immediate Effect: -

Long-Term Effect: YOU ARE VERY DEAD
Your gun or weapon is damaged and you suffer a −1 penalty when using it from now on, or an important item breaks.
You stumble, slip or trip.  Lose your next slow  action.

You drop your weapon,  lose your reins or  otherwise lose your grip  on something important.  If it was keeping you  upright or on your feet  you may need to make  a MOVE roll to avoid a  worse outcome.
Your attack is under- powered, or your action is  weak. Lose a 6 from your  pool of successes.
You are thrown off  balance. Lose your next  Round.
Your Troubles are  mounting—reroll on the  next column.
(2) TROUBLE OUTCOME TABLE - CONFLICT / PHYSICAL
You are bashed and  battered. Suffer 1 point  of either Hurts or Shakes  (GM decides).
You trip and fall, or are  thrown from your horse,  and are Prone. A fall  from height may cause  further damage.
Your bullet was a dud, or  your deadly blow wasn’t  as good as you thought.  An otherwise successful  attack does no damage.

You’re badly shaken by  the turn of events. Until  the end of the scene, you  suffer Trouble on a roll  of 1 or 2, but may recover  by taking a slow action  to draw breath, and  spending 1 Faith Point.
Your action results in  an impact on a random  bystander or unintended  target. They suffer a 4  dice attack, dam 1, crit 2.
Your Troubles are  mounting—reroll on the  next column.
(3) TROUBLE OUTCOME TABLE - CONFLICT / PHYSICAL
You catch yourself on  your stirrup, on a sharp  object, or bash into  something hard. You  suffer a 4 dice attack,  dam 1, crit 2.
Hang fire. Your gun  doesn’t go off but then  discharges next Round.  Or, your blow is slow  and cumbersome: you  lose your next Round  recovering.
You’re shaken and  shocked. For the rest of  the scene you suffer -2  to all rolls that use the  ability that suffered the  Trouble.
Your attack or action  affects a random  bystander or unintended  target. Either apply the  effect of the attack to  that target, or they suffer  a 6 dice attack, dam 1  crit 1.
Your gun explodes, your  weapon breaks and slices  into you or your blow  catches something sharp.  You suffer a 6 dice attack,  either with Damage  and Crit rating of your  weapon or dam 1, crit 1.
Your Troubles are  mounting—reroll on the  next column.
(4) TROUBLE OUTCOME TABLE - CONFLICT / PHYSICAL
You’re so shaken and  shocked by events that,  for the next Shift, you  suffer Trouble on a roll of  1 or 2. You may recover  by taking a slow action  to draw breath, and  spending 2 Faith Points.
Your action has gone  catastrophically wrong. A  key item of great value is  broken beyond repair, or  your horse is killed.

You trip and fall, or  are thrown from your  horse, and are Prone.  Take falling damage if  the fall is far enough.  You are Stunned for  D6 Rounds minus the  number of successes on a  RESILIENCE test.
Your attack or action  has terribly affected a  random nearby bystander.  They are immediately  Broken on Grit and  suffer a critical injury.
You have bashed yourself  terribly in some way, and  are immediately Broken  on Grit.
You have bashed yourself  terribly in some way, and  are immediately Broken  on Quick.
You have upset someone  with your words or  actions: they react badly  towards you, laugh at you,  or show you no respect.  Suffer a −1 penalty to  your next roll when  dealing with this person.
You get tongue-tied or  lose your thread. Lose  your next slow action.
You’re confused, your  mind goes blank, or  you lose your train of  thought. You suffer −1 to  rolls relating to this issue  for the rest of the scene.
They know you’re faking  it, and you know they  know you’re faking it.  Lose one 6 from your  pool of successes.
Your words or actions  have gone down very  badly, and you bluster  to cover it up. Lose your  next Round.
Your Troubles are  mounting—reroll on the  next column.
(2) TROUBLE OUTCOME TABLE - MENTAL / SOCIAL
Your confidence is badly  shaken. Suffer 1 point of  either Vexes or Doubts  (GM decides).
You’re tongue-tied. You  suffer a −1 penalty on all  ability rolls relating to  social or mental tests for  the rest of the scene.
Either directly or through  the grapevine, people  get to know of your bad  showing. For the rest  of the scenario, all your  ability rolls relating to  social encounters suffer a  −1 penalty.

You’re badly shaken by  the turn of events. Until  the end of the scene, you  suffer Trouble on a roll  of 1 or 2, but may recover  by taking a slow action  to draw breath, and  spending 1 Faith Point.
You’ve made such a pig’s  ear of the situation that  the object of your efforts  dismisses you. You cannot  try to influence them  again for at least 24  hours.
Your Troubles are  mounting—reroll on the  next column.
(3) TROUBLE OUTCOME TABLE - MENTAL / SOCIAL
You get so frustrated that  you suffer 1 point of both  Vexes and Doubts.
You struggle to cope with  the situation. Lose your  next Round to compose  yourself.
Your actions seem  so disrespectful or  disgraceful that a nearby  non-player character  (NPC) attacks you with  a slap or a punch to put  you in your place.
Things are going badly  wrong, and you can’t  cope. You need a Turn to  pull yourself together.
The shameful experience  scars you, and you suffer  a 6 dice attack, dam 1,  against your Docity and  Cunning.
Your Troubles are  mounting—reroll on the  next column.
(4) TROUBLE OUTCOME TABLE - MENTAL / SOCIAL
You’re so shaken or  shocked by events that,  for the next Shift, you  suffer Trouble on a roll of  1 or 2. You may recover  by taking a slow action  to draw breath, and  spending 2 Faith Points.
You have mortally  offended someone with  your words or actions.  They will hold a grudge  forever.
You’re confused, your  mind goes blank, or  you lose your train of  thought. You suffer −1 to  rolls relating to this issue  for the rest of the scene.
News of your abject  behavior gets around  town in a flash. For the  rest of the scenario, all  your ability rolls relating  to social encounters  suffer a −2 penalty.
Your efforts have gone so  disastrously wrong you  are immediately Broken  on Cunning. This makes  you upset, angry or  distraught. Roleplay the  outcome.
Your efforts have gone so  disastrously wrong you  are immediately Broken  on Docity. This makes  you doubtful, confused,  or distraught. Roleplay  the outcome.
